pros: Exceptional and friendly team that complement each other very well. Good learning opportunities for trainees.
cons: Very little to no engagement from senior staff following completion of training schemes. Often leaving personnel with very little option but to look elsewhere for other opportunities, which for a hospital that struggles with recruitment and retention is short sighted and bordering on negligent. When questioned on lack of resource management more often than not respond with "it's under review", the problem being it has been "under review" for over five years.

job_title: ICU Registered Nurse in Banbury, England
pros: Good organisation to work for but need a lot to do with diversity and equal opportunities.
cons: Their assessment of foreigners is tougher than the native English people. They would always find something to fail you expel you, make you feel like you are not part of this world. There is a lot of politics among senior staff but they don't want to talk about it. the certain staff gets favors for going longer holidays just because they are friends with managers or leads. Working in ICU just because you are a black nurse , you would always have to take a difficult patient. Some people are so proud that even working in the same team, they would not say hello to you. That's the reason IM LEAVING, this work place is toxic but they do not want you to talk about it. Just keep the fake smile hiding behind the mask.

pros:
Good holiday, pension (if you can budget for the redicolous contributions - upto 12%), can be flexible, free parking at main 'admin' site (non hospital)
Good research hospital with dealings with the University
cons:
Lack of motivation from all staff
Long notice period
No reward for good work and passed exams 
Hierarchical - almost all decisions come from the top with no consultation
Hard to park and expensive at the hospitals

High turnover and high vacancies accross the board

job_title: Practice Development Nurse in Oxford, England
pros: Excellent support and professional development opportunities. A strong team ethic in the department where I work and with lots of energy.
cons: Too expensive to live in Oxfordshire-  we should have "London weighting", to enable us to live and enjoy Oxford/Oxfordshire, many of us live out of area and commute and this leads to more tiredness, and possibly more "burn out".

pros: Very patient focused, some of the best and most dedicated nursing staff in the country I've ever had the pleasure to work with.
cons: Some parts of the hospitals are in a dreadful state and were built during WW2 and haven't been upgraded since. Parking is an absolute nightmare on all four hospital sites, and regularly can take in excess of an hour just to get off site.

pros:
Flexible working patterns
Laid back atmosphere
Easy work, but boring
cons:
Pay is awful but you expect that.
No merit based financial rewards; a useless person who has been in the job 10 years will be on max salary, and no matter how good you are policy means you have to wait for a small wage increase each year.
It's the NHS - so about 20 years behind regular business.
No desire for real change; very much a 'keep the ssip afloat' approach.
Limited by the ability of colleagues

review_title: Good if you can cope with the politically driven changes in priority
pros: Genuine attempt by management to involve the staff in development and implementation of strategy.  Most staff are motivated to do the right things.
cons: Insufficient resources.  Lots of projects get started but many lose momentum and peter out.  External pressures from government make it impossible for the organisation to in charge of its own destiny.
